entry.title: Mastering Wastewater Compliance with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS environment management
entry.content:
Wastewater Management using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS environment management enables a systematic and auditable process to monitor wastewater flows and parameters across your operations.

What is wastewater?

Wastewater is used water from industrial processes (including stormwater) that is no longer clean is categorized as wastewater. In industrial settings, it must be treated onsite or offsite at a publicly operated treatment facility before discharge to the environment.

Why Monitor Wastewater?

In industrial operations, wastewater is among the most tightly regulated environmental media. Regulators require facilities to not only comply with discharge permits but also to maintain robust systems for ongoing monitoring, recordkeeping, and reporting. Effective wastewater monitoring demonstrates proactive management of discharge parameters such as flow, pH, temperature, and contaminant concentrations—ensuring control over both volume and quality.

Beyond compliance, continuous monitoring provides valuable operational insights that help identify process inefficiencies, prevent permit exceedances, and support long-term environmental performance improvements.

Managing Wastewater discharges enables organizations to:
    •    Monitor discharged volumes by area and source 
    •    Evaluate discharge results against legal and internal thresholds
    •    Detect deviations from expected discharge profiles
    •    Support environmental reporting and inspection readiness
    •    Strengthen audibility and data tracking

Wastewater Management features of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS environment management:

The solution provides a comprehensive ability to track wastewater outflows, organized by source, time period, and parameter, including:

  • Total volume per discharge point
  • Parameter-specific results
  • Calculation of pollutant loadings
  • Comparison with permitted limits
  • Identification of missing or delayed data
  • Compliance status summaries
  • Permit Management

Benefits

  • Demonstrated operational compliance and license to operate
  • Reduced treatment costs through improved process control
  • Efficient collection of sustainability metrics


Next steps

Use the links below to configure and test the wastewater management functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS environment management.
    •    Step-by-step configuration guide
    •    Standard test scenario with sample data

To follow the full series, subscribe to the SAP Environment, Health, and Safety Management tag and stay informed about upcoming publications.

entry.title: Prodction Supply Area is missing in reservation (261)
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

we are using a delivery based Integration between SAP PP and SAP EWM. 

We have maintained a Kanban Control Cycle (PK05), where the IM Storage Location is maintained. Kanban Process works as expected. We have also some products, which are needed less frequent in production, so we use movement type 261 in migo for a consumption against a manufacturing order for these components. 

We have noticed that the delivery generated by this process has the wrong document type in EWM because the two fields HEADER_DATA_SPL-INITIATOR_PROCESS / ITEM_DATA_SPL-SUPPLYAREA in the queue container are empty. HEADER_DATA_SPL-INITIATOR_PROCESS has to be PCD to determine the right ewm document type. ITEM_DATA_SPL-SUPPLYAREA should contain the Production Supply Area. 

We have discovered that the PSA is taken from the reservation into the delivery and the PSA was already missing in the reservation (Table RESB). 


Storage Location 0002 is EWM managed where 7100 is IM managed. We have maintained another Control Cycle for the Supply Area, which we use for Kanban (LPK1) where the Destination Storage Location is IM managend, and the Source Storage Loacation is EWM managed. 

When we maintain Source and Destination Storage Location both 0002 (both EWM managed), then the PSA is taken over into the reservation and the following process is working. 

The Supply Area is maintained in the workcenter (CR03) which is used in the manufacturing order, so actually the Supply Area from the workcenter should be taken over into the reservation, but that did not work right now. 

Is it possible, to use the same Production Supply Area for Kanban and Consumption against Manufacturing Orders (261)? 

Thanks in advance for everyone who is trying to help.

Best regards,
Nicolas

entry.title: Premium Hub CoE - From SAP Event Management to GTT: Integration Strategies Across TM Versions
entry.content:
Introduction

For more than a decade, SAP Event Management (EM) has been a key component of logistics visibility — capturing milestones, monitoring deviations, and enabling event-driven processes.

However, as supply chains became increasingly networked and data-driven, SAP introduced a new generation solution:
#SAP Business Network for Logistics-Global Track and Trace (BN4L–GTT).

GTT brings cloud-based scalability, real-time visibility, and integration with visibility providers like Project44, Transporeon, and Shippeo.

Still, many customers operate in hybrid landscapes, where legacy SAP TM (9.x) or ECC systems coexist with S/4HANA.

This post explains how EM and GTT differ, why they cannot run in parallel in the same system, and how organizations can plan a smooth transition across versions.

🔍Understanding EM and GTT

While EM focuses on internal milestone tracking, GTT is designed for network collaboration and predictive visibility.

 

FeatureSAP Event Management (EM)SAP Business Network – Global Track & Trace (GTT)
ArchitectureOn-premise, ABAP-based (ECC or standalone)Cloud-based (SAP Business Network)
IntegrationIDoc / Proxy / PI interfacesREST APIs, standard extractors, BN4L integration
Data ModelEvent handler objects and expected eventsBusiness documents (FO, FB, Delivery) + actual events
ScopeInternal process visibilityEnd-to-end, cross-company, real-time visibility
ExtensibilityBAdIs, custom EM structuresEvent-to-Action scripting, open APIs
Provider IntegrationNot supportedIntegrated with Project44, Transporeon, FourKites, etc.

 

⚠️EM and GTT Cannot Run in Parallel

One of the most common questions is whether EM can remain active while integrating GTT into the same TM or ERP system.

Short answer: No – not in the same instance.

Both EM and GTT rely on event extraction logic from logistics documents (e.g., FOs, FUs, deliveries).

EM and GTT extraction codes cannot be activated together in the same system without conflicts in event extraction logic.

This leads to conflicts such as:

  • Duplicate or missing event messages

  • Interrupted event handler updates

  • Inconsistent milestone confirmations

SAP officially confirms that EM and GTT cannot be used together on the same system due to shared technical dependencies.

References:
SAP Note: 3556097 - SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace: Integration to TM in S/4HANA
Statement on EM coexistence: Global Track and Trace Prerequisites

Recommended paths:
  • Plan a phased transition off EM to BN4L–GTT for strategic longevity.

⚙️Integration Challenges Across System Versions

Challenge:

Many logistics customers still operate on SAP TM 9.x (SP09) or ECC-based systems, which are not directly compatible with the SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace (BN4L–GTT) standard extractor.
SAP’s standard GTT extractor is officially supported only from SAP S/4HANA 1909 SP03 onward.

At the same time, several customers continue to rely on classic SAP Event Management (EM) logic within TM or ECC environments, which they wish to maintain for historical or operational reasons.


ScenarioDescriptionRemarks
SAP S/4HANA TM (2023 FPS03 or higher)Use the standart extractor codes.Ensure system prerequisites and SAP Notes are implemented. (Using Standard Extractor Codes)
SAP TM 9.x / ECC SystemsLegacy TM version not compatible with BN4L–GTT standard extractor (SAP Note 3556097) Requires custom or sample extractors (How to Integrate SAP ECC/SAP TM (standalone) With GTT)
S/4HANA 1909 SP03+Embedded TM with GTT sample extractor codes and BN4L integrationRecommended standard setup(Using Sample Extractor Codes )
Hybrid TM (9.4 + S/4HANA)Legacy pre-carriage with S/4 on-carriagePartial GTT via SO/STO correlation keys(Sample Code Configuration Guide for Integration )

Next Steps

  • Run a PoC focused on system landscape and representative flow.
  • Prioritize migration of legacy TM flows to S/4HANA TM for native GTT extractor support.
  • Design a phased EM decommission strategy; centralize visibility on BN4L–GTT.
  • Establish governance for keys, error handling, and monitoring across all legs and systems.
If you’d like a tailored architecture review or a PoC blueprint, reach out to your SAP account team or SAP CoE.
 
Learn more about SAP Premium Engagement and how a global team of experts can help you to get the most out of your SAP solutions.

If you already are a Premium Engagement customer, contact your Technical Quality Manager (TQM) to discuss how Premium Engagement services can help you with a custom-tailored and efficient service portfolio to make your process mining initiative a success!

entry.title: RAP API with custom static action: How can I set optional parameters?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I defined a API using RAP. Here below all the details.

ROOT ENTITY

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Sales Report (SLSRPT from Lobster)'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZLBSR_R_SALES_DATA
  as select from zsd_lbstr_slsrpt
{
  key uuid               as UUID,
      erdat              as CreationDate,
      erzet              as CreationTime,
      ernam              as CreationUser,
      status             as Status,
      bstkd              as CustomerReference,
      bstdk              as CustomerReferenceDate,
      ean11              as ArticleEAN11,
//      @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'QuantityUnitOfMeasure'
      kwmeng             as Quantity,
      vrkme              as QuantityUnitOfMeasure,
      vdatu              as RequestedDeliveryDate,
      sold_to_party_gln  as SoldToPartyGLN,
      ship_to_party_gln  as ShipToPartyGLN,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true
      local_last_changed as LocalLastChanged,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true
      last_changed       as LastChanged
}

BEHAVIOUR DEFINITION

managed implementation in class zbp_lbsr_r_sales_data unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZLBSR_R_SALES_DATA alias SalesData
persistent table zsd_lbstr_slsrpt
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
etag master LastChanged
{
  field ( readonly )
  UUID,
  CreationDate,
  CreationTime,
  CreationUser,
  Status,
  LastChanged,
  LocalLastChanged;
  field ( numbering : managed )
  UUID;

  create;
  update;
  delete;

  determination fill_administrative_data on save { create; }

  static action deleteWithFilters parameter ZLBSR_D_DELETION_FILTERS;

  mapping for zsd_lbstr_slsrpt
    {
      UUID                  = uuid;
      CreationDate          = erdat;
      CreationTime          = erzet;
      CreationUser          = ernam;
      Status                = status;
      CustomerReference     = bstkd;
      CustomerReferenceDate = bstdk;
      ArticleEAN11          = ean11;
      Quantity              = kwmeng;
      QuantityUnitOfMeasure = vrkme;
      RequestedDeliveryDate = vdatu;
      SoldToPartyGLN        = sold_to_party_gln;
      ShipToPartyGLN        = ship_to_party_gln;
      LocalLastChanged      = local_last_changed;
      LastChanged           = last_changed;
    }
}

ABSTRACT ENTITY ZLBSR_D_DELETION_FILTERS

@EndUserText.label: 'Sales Report - Filters for deleteWithFilters action'
define abstract entity ZLBSR_D_DELETION_FILTERS
{
  CustomerReference : bstkd;
  SoldToPartyGLN    : zlbstr_slsrpt_sold_to_prty_gln;
  ShipToPartyGLN    : zlbstr_slsrpt_ship_to_prty_gln;
}

The 3 fields CustomerReference, SoldToPartyGLN and ShipToPartyGLN are all character fields with different lenghts.

When I send a POST request for the action deleteWithFilters I have always to declare the value for all the 3 parameters. I could always declare the ShipToPartyGLN as empty (like "ShipToPartyGLN": "") and that works but I'd like to set the ShipToPartyGLN as optional in order to avoid the caller to set this parameter everytime. How can I do that?

 

Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Replication Flows Blog Series Part 8 – Confluent as a Replication Source
Re: VA05 Layout problems
entry.content:
Below are some of the reasons why new user Layout columns are not displayed in VA05

User-specific layouts (saved via ALV grid) are stored in SAP memory or user settings, not in the same place as default or global layouts. If your Z report is retrieving default/global layouts, it may not be accessing the user-specific layout you saved with new columns.

Layouts are stored in table LVC_S_LAYO or SALV layouts depending on the ALV type. User layouts are often stored in table LTDX or LTDXT, keyed by Report name / User ID / Layout variant name

Ensure your Z report is referencing the exact layout name and report ID used when saving the layout in VA05. If the layout was saved under a different transaction or program name, it won’t be recognized.

What you can do is go to SE16N to inspect LTDX/LTDXT for your layout. Confirm the layout is saved under the correct report name and user ID. Check if the layout includes the new columns in the field catalog. Also, in your Z report, ensure you are using REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY or CL_GUI_ALV_GRID correctly, Passing the correct layout name via IS_VARIANT and updating the field catalog to include all desired columns

entry.title: Re: T5UTKZ VA Marital Status Entry
entry.content:
Hi Rosette,

Thank you for reaching out.

To address the incorrect entry for VA marital status 15 in the table T5UTKZ, please refer to SAP Note 3649258 (BSI: Invalid filing status and missing delimitations in T5UTKZ table). This note addresses the issue where some entries were not properly delimited in the BSI Filing Status (T5UTKZ) table, even though they are correctly delimited in the ReturnMaritalStatusInfoForFormula API in BSI TaxFactory™.

Here are the steps to resolve the issue:

  1. Apply SAP Note 3649258.
  2. Run the Synchronize Payroll Tax Data (RPUPAYUS_SYNC_TAX_DATA) report.

With this note installed, the system will update around 150 entries in the T5UTKZ table.

After completing these steps, please retest the scenario. If the issue persists, kindly create a customer case for further assistance.

Best regards,
Lucas Ody

entry.title: Re: Stability Should Not Be Optional: Ongoing Challenges...
entry.content:
Hello @benroberg 

Thank you for your message and for confirming that the issues have been escalated to the product team.

That said, I have to share again that these problems are not new. They’ve been recurring for over five years now. My data team supports more than 50 SuccessFactors clients, all of whom regularly encounter major difficulties with Story. Each time a ticket is opened but the instabilities are soon replaced by another one and then another one. Several of these cases were even handled through Global Escalations this year, involving direct contact with the product team, who are therefore fully aware of these challenges. Unfortunately, all those clients came out of the process disappointed, with their confidence in both the tool and the team behind it seriously shaken.

Given that we have these 50+ clients who report the same issues and whom we actively support, I find it hard to understand how these 50+ clients would be any different from all the others and why they would be the only ones experiencing problems with Story.

Just this morning, during a training session, we ran (again) into multiple error messages that make it very hard to promote Story as a reliable solution. Many users still prefer sticking to Tables whenever possible, simply to avoid the instability of Story until the situation improves.

On the development side, it’s also discouraging to see that some key features have been on the roadmap since…2022 and are still not available (maybe for 2026, but maybe not). The fact these announcements are revised multiple times makes the securing of resources and budget for customers very complicated. To make things worse, several recurring bugs and inconsistent behaviors point to deeper technical and quality issues. My “favorite” example is an issue from last week where not only do we get an error in an error that is not the right error, but also an error in the displayed error message (!!!) https://me.sap.com/notes/3667892.

Without a major shift in how this product is managed and stabilized, it’s extremely difficult for us to trust Story or recommend that our clients build their reports with this technology rather than the legacy tools.

Best regards,

Executives, procurement teams, and consultants are increasingly asking AI engines like ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, and Perplexity questions such as:

entry.title: SAP Connect Recap: Empowering Suppliers on SAP Business Network
entry.content:
SAP Connect, held in Las Vegas October 6-8, was a beneficial gathering for SAP customers, shedding light on key innovations that promise to revolutionize supply chain management. Here are some highlights that are particularly exciting for suppliers on SAP Business Network. 

Roadmap and future innovations:  

The much-anticipated roadmap breakout introduced the future vision for the supplier account, giving users more visibility, control, and growth on the network. An exciting piece of news is that all SAP customers on S/4 Hana Public Cloud now have the possibility to search for any supplier on SAP Business Network. This represents a huge pool of new opportunities for network suppliers to catch.  

Watch the on-demand replay of the supplier roadmap session here. 

Domain Blocks and Temporary Account: Enhanced Account Management Control 

One of the standout topics was the introduction of domain blocks, which garnered significant interest among suppliers. This feature is part of a broader journey aimed at giving suppliers more control over account and entity management, and at helping buyers with their sourcing and supplier onboarding activities. 

In a nutshell, the admin of the parent account can claim its domain name and control permissions on the creation of new network accounts with the same domain name. The new options include blocking the creation of new accounts, or permitting the creation of a temporary account, an account limited in features and in time. This ensures a smooth solution for time-sensitive situations yet avoids cluttering the network with more unmanaged accounts. 

These expanded blocking options give suppliers the ability to control the proliferation of accounts more effectively, addressing a longstanding pain point in sourcing activities and supply chain management. 

More information on domain blocking coming soon. 

SAP Business Network, promote subscription: Connecting buyers with credible suppliers 

Another hot topic was the SAP Business Network, promote subscription. Both suppliers and buyers showed keen interest in how this offering can help buyers find credible sources of supply— and how suppliers can ensure they show up in that search. With over 80,000 buyer searches and 36,000 Discovery posts annually, getting discovered is more important than ever. 

Learn more about promote subscription features and benefits. 

Leveraging AI for efficiency 

Artificial intelligence was a major focus of each solution area. For SAP Business Network, it meant improvements in onboarding and invoice dispute management. AI-driven solutions streamline these processes, saving valuable time and reducing manual effort. For suppliers, this means smoother interactions and faster resolution of issues, leading to improved overall efficiency. 

Read more on GenAI invoice error classification here. 

Invoicing compliance  

With a growing number of countries putting in place e-invoicing mandates, compliance with evolving requirements worldwide is on the mind of all trading organizations. SAP Business Network is committed to remaining compliant, and presented its broad vision as well as specific solutions for the upcoming country mandates, including Belgium and Poland.  

Make sure to keep checking our Community page for the latest information.  

 Conclusion 

SAP Connect highlighted the strides being made in supply chain technology, with a clear focus on empowering suppliers. The introduction of domain blocks offers unparalleled control over account management, while the SAP Business Network, promote subscription helps to forge stronger, more credible partnerships. Moreover, the incorporation of AI in key processes underscores SAP’s commitment to innovation and efficiency. These advancements are set to transform the way suppliers and buyers engage, paving the way for more streamlined and effective operations across sourcing, procurement, and supply chain.

entry.title: Second Half 2025 Release: What’s New in SAP SuccessFactors HCM?
entry.content:
In today’s business climate, only one thing is certain—change. Whether it’s widening skills gaps, increasing cost pressures, or unexpected disruptions, organizations across all industries are feeling the strain. But with the right strategy and tools in place, HR leaders can confidently navigate this new era of uncertainty and turn every change into an opportunity.

With the SAP SuccessFactors HCM Second Half 2025 Release, we are delivering more than 350 innovations across all solution areas, enabling you to work smarter, move faster, and build a workforce that’s ready for whatever comes next. Here’s a snapshot of what you can expect to see in this release:

 

Drive better people and business decisions

People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud
We are excited to announce the general availability of our new people analytics solution, People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud. This offering empowers organizations to make smarter, faster workforce decisions by unifying SAP and third-party data. Intuitive dashboards and AI-driven insights allow customers to answer critical questions across the employee lifecycle. In this initial release, we are delivering nine pre-built use cases, each designed to unlock insights in a specific HR domain. These include workforce composition, compensation, skills, recruiting, learning, performance, goals, succession, and career development.

Skills and compensation insights

 

Enable agile and compliant HR

New home page
We are launching a completely refreshed home page that provides a more intuitive, efficient, and personalized user experience. A refined layout surfaces timely information and reduces scrolling and clicks, enabling users to complete tasks with ease. Additionally, custom banners allow administrators to create engaging, brand-aligned communications and announcements for targeted audiences, while data visualization cards bring KPIs and metrics directly to the home page. This new experience is initially available as “opt-in” and is supported on both desktop and mobile devices.

New home page on desktop and mobile

 

People Profile Enhancements
We have completed the refresh of the People Profile view experience, incorporating valuable customer input and feedback. This brings us one step closer to the universal release. In addition, customers can now leverage optimized experiences for updating employee information and navigating historical changes. New full-page views enable users to quickly insert, edit, or delete records, further simplifying employee data management.

New edit and history experiences in the People Profile

 

SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling
We are thrilled to introduce a brand-new shift scheduling solution, SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling. Specifically tailored for organizations in manufacturing and other production industries, this solution enables demand-driven workforce planning, supporting both weekly and monthly shift plans that account for operational requirements, employee skills, and labor regulations. By optimizing scheduling and providing clear visibility into workforce availability, organizations can minimize downtime, increase productivity, and better align labor supply with business demand.

SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling

 

Geofencing in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking
In this release, customers can leverage a new geofencing feature that helps ensure employees clock in and out only when physically present at their designated work location. Geofences can be defined for specific groups, with real-time visibility into proximity, helping to improve compliance with location-based policies and prevent time recording outside authorized areas.

Geofencing

 

Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) support in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
Organizations in the United States can now connect with FMLA service providers to automate leave deduction and share inbound data, such as case IDs and dates. This capability helps ensure more accurate leave management, simplifies compliance, and reduces overall administrative effort.

Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) support

 

Create a future-ready workforce

Performance and Goals Agent
A new performance and goals agent offers data-informed coaching for more meaningful conversations and performance reviews. This agent—within the SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals solution—analyzes employee data, such as performance goals, activities and achievements, and continuous feedback, to create a tailored discussion agenda for each employee. Using Joule, managers receive AI-guided insights, including progress summaries, key accomplishments, growth focus areas, and development recommendations. Users can ask follow-up questions to dive deeper into any of these areas.

Performance and Goals Agent

 

Business rules integration in performance management
Business rules can now be used to trigger actions for users based on predefined conditions during the performance review process, such as dynamically exposing a comment field only when a rating condition is met. This standardized review process enhances transparency, reduces bias, and helps ensure that feedback is aligned with organizational policies.

Business rules in performance management

 

Skills-based successor recommendations
Customers can now use AI to quickly identify highly qualified successors by analyzing skills, proficiency levels, and work experiences in employee growth portfolios. This enables greater visibility into potential successors that might have been overlooked using traditional approaches and metrics.

Skills-based successor recommendations

 

People-based model for talent and learning
We are introducing a people-based model across our learning and talent solutions, enabling a more consistent and connected experience for employees and managers. By linking key data, such as learning, skills, and performance, to the individual rather than a specific job role, users benefit from fewer data gaps, more accurate insights, and a more connected and efficient approach to managing growth and development. Whether tracking development or planning succession, all relevant information remains aligned to the person, creating a more complete view of each individual that supports more targeted development and upskilling.

 

Learn more

These are just a few of the many innovations in the SAP SuccessFactors Second Half 2025 Release. To learn more, check out the resources below:

  • Visit the SAP SuccessFactors Product Release & Road Map Information page for release documentation, product videos, and solution area blogs
  • Watch the 2H 2025 Release Highlights Overview Video, featuring Bianka Woelke, GVP Head of Application Product Management
  • Discover all innovations in the What's New Viewer

Similarly, for an overview of all the sessions of interest for mobile development, including abstracts, see:

entry.title: How to attach the billing document PDF into XML for eInvoice Belgium in SAP S/4Hana Public Cloud?
entry.content:
Hi,

We configured Peppol for Belgium and sending and receiving works.

We are on public cloud and would like to attach the customer billing document PDF to the XML (DRC) send to the end customer.

Can you please guide us how to do this? Any BAdI is available?

 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to attach the billing document PDF into XML for e...
entry.content:
• In the Peppol network, documents are exchanged in a structured format by using XML files. Additional documents can be added to the XML file during submission.
  • Implementation of Business Add-In (BAdI) is required to embed attachments into the XML as binary-encoded file or as link to an external source, the following BAdIs are available:
    • Peppol: Filling of Invoice XML Files
    • Peppol: Filling of Credit Note

 

For more details refer to the Knowledge based article : 3672017 - Embed billing document PDF attachment into XML for eInvoice Belgium in SAP S/4Hana Public Cloud

entry.title: Recap: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Virtual Summit 2025 – A Global Dialogue
entry.content:
It began with a simple question in the chat: “Where are you joining from?” Within moments, responses lit up the screen — Bangalore, Tokyo, Singapore. Then came São Leopoldo, Paris, Buenos Aires, and Berlin. The SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Virtual Summit 2025 was underway, and it was clear: this isn’t just an annual virtual event — it is truly a global dialogue.

From the first keynote to the final Q&A, the summit reflected the shared challenges and ambitions of compliance professionals across continents. Whether navigating new tax mandates or exploring AI-powered reporting, this community of SAP customers, partners and SAP experts came together on September 25 to learn, connect, and shape the future of digital compliance.

With 4,400 registrants and over 1,350 participants dialing-in from nearly every continent, this year’s summit reaffirmed its role as a global platform for collaboration, innovation, and learning.

From Strategy to Execution: Empowering Global Compliance

The event opened with a keynote by Sergey Shvedov, SVP and Chief Product Officer of SAP Globalization, who outlined SAP’s strategy on end-to-end compliance worldwide. He emphasized SAP’s four-pillar strategy: Global coverage, continuous legal updates, extensibility, and audit-ready processes to help customers navigate evolving regulatory landscapes.

Customer Voices: Real-World Journeys and Lessons

This year’s summit spotlighted customer stories that brought SAP Document and Reporting Compliance to life:

  • Jubin Sharma from Nestlé shared their journey implementing SAP Document and Reporting Compliance to streamline tax and reporting processes across multiple regions.
  • Pedro Castro from SumUp demonstrated how SAP Document and Reporting Compliance accelerated invoice processing and payment cycles, improving operational agility.
  • Crimson Partners, joined by their customer Roche, delivered a joint session that showcased how partner-driven expertise can help customers scale compliance globally with one process and one solution. While Roche leverages Crimson’s support in specific countries, the session highlighted how collaborative planning and technical alignment — enabled by SAP Document and Reporting Compliance — can streamline implementation and daily operations across diverse jurisdictions.

These sessions underscored how SAP Document and Reporting Compliance is not just a compliance tool, but a strategic enabler for transforming compliance operations.

Innovation in Action and Practical Guidance

The event also brought SAP experts to address the latest roadmap updates and product enhancements. Topics ranged from smarter e-invoicing and AI-driven reporting to localization of cash flow statements and extensibility frameworks for universal coverage.

The summit concluded with a practical overview session offering configuration tips and implementation best practices — making the full set of recordings a valuable resource for both strategic and hands-on guidance.

Access the Information Package

All session recordings and slides are now available in the Information Package. Whether you attended live or are catching up, we invite you to explore the materials and continue the conversation.

Thank you to all the attendees, speakers, customers and partners who contributed to making this event a resounding success. Your participation and engagement are the driving force of this community.

While the summit is wrapped up, the journey towards mastering compliance is ongoing. Stay tuned for upcoming events, webinars, and resources from SAP that will continue to support your compliance journey.

We look forward to welcoming you to our next events as we continue to unlock the future of compliance together.

Learn more about SAP’s localized solutions at sap.com/localization and join our Localization community.

entry.title: Hands-On with AI: A Product Manager’s Journey with Llama.cpp and LiteLLM
entry.content:
Why Product Managers Should Get Their Hands Dirty with AI

Generative AI is transforming software and business, and product managers can’t afford to treat it as a black box. We’ve all seen impressive AI demos, but often the gap between those flashy demos and actual product performance is substantial. The best way to truly understand what’s happening under the hood is to roll up our sleeves and experiment ourselves. In fact, experienced AI product managers emphasize that deploying models and learning from those mistakes firsthand is the surest way to build intuition about AI capabilities.

As a Senior Product Manager at SAP Labs, I’m surrounded by buzz around AI- from SAP’s Business Technology Platform (BTP) now offering easy access to a range of large language models for developers, to SAP’s new AI copilot Joule which uses generative AI grounded in business data to proactively assist users in SAP applications. In this environment, I realized that to have meaningful conversations with my team and to envision product features, I needed to be a bit hands-on with AI. There’s no substitute for building something yourself to grasp the potential and limitations of these technologies. 

From C# Developer to Product Manager to AI Tinkerer: Reconnecting with My Coding Roots

Before moving into product management, I spent years as a C# developer and software architect. That coding background turned out to be a superpower when I decided to demystify AI by actually building a mini AI solution myself. I deliberately stepped away from SAP and other Hyperscalers toolset (no Bedrock, SAP Business AI here!) and dived into the world of open-source AI tooling. By converting some known code patterns and hand-wiring every piece of the solution, I forced myself to learn how it all works in practice. This hands-on exercise was far more enlightening than any number of AI webinars I could have watched.

My approach was simple: start with what I know (C# and system architecture) and incrementally add the unfamiliar (AI models and libraries). Instead of abstract slide decks, I had a running program on my laptop that I could poke and prod. This way, I was not just reading about transformers and large language models- I was experiencing them. Each integration hiccup and error message along the way taught me something new about AI. For example, figuring out why a model file wasn’t loading made me learn about file formats and quantization- and which ones work best for Windows; adjusting API calls gave me insight into how prompt/response cycles work. It’s the kind of understanding you only get by doing.

 

Building My Own local LLM Stack: Llama.cpp, Models, and a Lite LLM Proxy

After some research, I settled on a stack that would let me run a Large Language Model (LLM) locally and interact with it as easily as if it were a cloud service. In a nutshell, my setup included the following components:

  • Llama.cpp: an open-source C/C++ library for running LLMs locally (efficient even on CPU).
  • Meta’s Llama 2 model: the actual AI model (I chose a smaller variant) – more on model naming in a moment.
  • LiteLLM Proxy server: a lightweight API gateway that makes the local model act like an OpenAI API endpoint.
  • Custom client code: a simple program (leveraging my C# skills) to send prompts and receive AI responses.

Why Llama.cpp? Running a model locally was important to me for a few reasons: avoiding cloud API costs, minimizing latency, and keeping my data private. Relying solely on cloud AI APIs isn’t always ideal – issues like latency, cost, and data privacy often drive developers to run models on-premise. Llama.cpp allowed me to do exactly that. It’s a project that enables even large models to run on commodity hardware by optimizing their memory usage. I stuck to a model that my laptop could handle (more on how models are sized below), and Llama.cpp handled the rest by efficiently utilizing my CPU. No GPU required for this.

.\llama-server.exe `
-m "C:\models\llama-3.1-8b-instruct-q4_k_m.gguf" `
-c 4096 `
--port 8000 `
--n-gpu-layers 0

Decoding Model Naming Conventions:
I finalized using this mode: llama-3.1-8b-instruct.q4_k_m.gguf- and here is what it means.
llama-3.1: Identifies the model's family and version. Llama is the name of the model series developed by Meta, and 3.1 is the specific version number, which was released in July 2024.
8b: Indicates the size of the model, representing 8 billion parameters. This refers to the number of variables within the model's neural network, which directly impacts its performance and the computational resources required to run it.
instruct: Denotes that this is an instruction-tuned version of the model. Instruction-tuned models have been fine-tuned on a dataset of instructions and helpful responses, making them optimized for conversational, assistant-like tasks.
q4_k_m: Specifies the quantization method applied to the model. Quantization is a technique that reduces the size and memory requirements of a model by lowering the precision of its weights.
q4: Refers to a 4-bit quantization, meaning the model's weights are compressed from a higher precision (like 32-bit floats) to 4-bit integers.
_k: Indicates the use of a more advanced, grouped quantization technique known as K-quantization. This method applies different quantization schemes to different parts of the model to maximize accuracy.
_m: Stands for "medium" and specifies the variant of the K-quantization. In this case, _m offers a balance between model size, speed, and accuracy. Other variants include _s (small/faster) and _l (large/more accurate).
gguf: Is the file format of the model. It is a new, unified format for storing large language models that is designed for ease of use with the llama.cpp project and is compatible across different hardware.

Adding a Lite LLM Proxy (and Why It Matters):
One challenge I discovered is that every AI model or service has its own API or SDK. If I wrote code directly for Llama.cpp, that code would be different from code calling, say, OpenAI’s GPT-4 or an Anthropic Claude model. As a product manager, I like flexibility- I might want to swap models or compare outputs easily. This is where the LiteLLM proxy came to the rescue. LiteLLM is a lightweight Python-based gateway that provides a unified, OpenAI-compatible API for many different models and providers. In simpler terms, it let me interface with my local Llama model as if I were calling the familiar OpenAI ChatGPT API. As the documentation puts it, “LiteLLM Proxy is an OpenAI-compatible gateway that allows you to interact with multiple LLM providers through a unified API”.
Why is this a big deal? Because it saved me from writing model-specific integration code. The LiteLLM proxy supports over 100 providers (open-source models, cloud APIs, etc.) through one standard interface. I could write my application logic once and then switch the model behind the scenes by just changing a config or model name string. For example, during testing I could swap from my local "llama2" model to, say, "gpt-3.5-turbo" from OpenAI with minimal code changes. LiteLLM handled all the translation of requests and responses in the background. It even offers nice features like logging, error handling, and centralized API key management for cloud models, but in my case the key feature was the standalone proxy server that I ran on localhost. This proxy exposed an endpoint (/v1/chat/completions) just like OpenAI’s, but it was backed by my Llama.cpp model. That means I could use existing OpenAI API client libraries or tools to talk to my model. In fact, my C# code was originally written to call OpenAI’s service- by simply pointing it to the LiteLLM proxy URL and using a dummy API key, it started talking to my AI instead!

Config.yaml file is the place major settings are done, here is mine: 

One can create another customized config file and use it while starting the LiteLLM: 

litellm --config .\litellm.config.yaml --port 4000

 


Bringing it All Together: With Llama.cpp running the model and LiteLLM providing an API wrapper, I had all the pieces needed to converse with my AI. Setting it up involved a few steps: downloading the model file, launching the Llama.cpp server, starting the LiteLLM proxy pointing to that local model, and then writing a test prompt from my client. The first time I saw the model generate a response to my question- completely offline and on my own hardware- was a eureka moment. The answers were nowhere near GPT-5 level, of course, but that wasn’t the point. The point was I had built a working LLM service myself, end-to-end. Every token it produced came from a model I hosted, triggered by C# code I wrote.

From Zero to LLM in Two Days (What I Learned)

Amazingly, from knowing next to nothing about how to run an AI model, I got this entire setup working over a weekend (about two days). This included plenty of Google searches, YouTube tutorials, hunting for the right model on huggingface, when things didn’t work on the first try. The speed of this learning-by-doing highlights how accessible AI tinkering has become. You don’t need to be a data scientist to experiment with these systems – if you have some coding background and a willingness to troubleshoot, you can get started fast. And if you don’t code, even then many tools (like Ollama or various GUIs for Llama.cpp) are making it one-click to try local AI. The barrier is lower than ever.
For product managers, the takeaway from my experience is clear: become fluent in AI by engaging with it directly. In the same way a PM for a database product should understand basic SQL, a PM in the age of AI should understand how LLMs are built and deployed. By building a toy version of an AI system, I learned about model limitations (e.g. smaller models can struggle with complex queries), the importance of prompt formatting, and the practical aspects of performance and memory. This knowledge is already influencing how I think about AI features in my product roadmap. I find myself asking better questions of my engineering teams and more critically evaluating vendor claims about “AI-powered” features.


Modernizing a Legacy Codebase: VB.NET to C# with Roslyn and AI

Fifteen years ago, I led a team of 10 developers as the technical lead on a major modernization project: migrating a large VB.NET codebase to C#. Back then, this was a massive undertaking. We relied on a brute-force rewrite approach, manually converting thousands of lines of code, coordinating across modules, and spending over six months to deliver a reliable result.
Recently, I revisited this challenge as a proof of concept (POC) to understand the impact of AI on our daily work. My goal was to see how modern open-source tools and AI could streamline what once required a large team and significant time investment. After a really long time, i rolled up my sleeves i starting coding in C# with VS-Code.

 

Ingest: Feeding the Entire Codebase as Input

The first step was ingesting the legacy VB.NET project. I decided to make the process as straightforward as possible: simply point the tool to the root folder of the codebase. The ingestion component recursively scanned the folder and gathered all source files. This approach ensured that full context was captured (all modules, classes, and dependencies) in one go, which would be vital for accurate analysis and conversion later. 

string inputFolder = @"C:\LegacyVBProject";
var vbFiles = Directory.GetFiles(inputFolder, "*.vb", SearchOption.AllDirectories);
Console.WriteLine($"Found {vbFiles.Length} VB files to process.");

By ingesting the entire folder, I removed the need for manually listing files or dealing with one file at a time. From a product perspective, this decision would reduce human error and save time- I can feed in an entire project and trust that all relevant code was captured for analysis. This also sets a solid foundation for the subsequent Roslyn analysis by ensuring we weren’t missing any pieces of the puzzle.

 

Analyze: Leveraging Roslyn for Deep Code Insights

With all code files in hand, the next phase was to analyze the VB.NET source using Microsoft’s Roslyn. Roslyn is the codename for the open-source .NET Compiler Platform, providing APIs to parse and inspect code for both C# and VB.NET. Essentially, Roslyn can read source code and produce a rich abstract syntax tree (AST) representation, along with semantic information. This was incredibly powerful- it meant that my tool could understand the structure of the VB.NET code programmatically. Why Roslyn? From a product manager’s viewpoint, I saw Roslyn to de-risk the conversion. By analyzing the code upfront, I could catch potential issues (like unsupported language features or complex syntax quirks) early. Roslyn’s API allowed us to load the entire project in a workspace and even compile it in memory to ensure there were no lurking compilation errors. Here’s a simplified look at how I used Roslyn in the tool:

MSBuildLocator.RegisterDefaults();
using var workspace = MSBuildWorkspace.Create();
var solution = await workspace.OpenSolutionAsync(slnPath);
var files = new List<object>();
var deps  = new List<(string From, string To)>();

foreach (var proj in solution.Projects.Where(p => p.Language == LanguageNames.VisualBasic))
{
    var compilation = await proj.GetCompilationAsync();
    foreach (var doc in proj.Documents)
    {
        var tree = await doc.GetSyntaxTreeAsync();
        var model = compilation!.GetSemanticModel(tree);

        if (tree is null) continue;
        var root  = await tree.GetRootAsync();
        var symbols = new List<object>();

        foreach (var node in root.DescendantNodes())
        {
            var symbol = model.GetDeclaredSymbol(node);
            if (symbol is IMethodSymbol ms)
            {
                symbols.Add(new {
                    Kind = "Method",
                    Name = ms.ToDisplayString(),
                    Parameters = ms.Parameters.Select(p => new { p.Name, Type = p.Type.ToDisplayString() }),
                    Returns = ms.ReturnType.ToDisplayString(),
                    Accessibility = ms.DeclaredAccessibility.ToString()
                });

                foreach (var child in node.DescendantNodes())
                {
                    var called = model.GetSymbolInfo(child).Symbol as IMethodSymbol;
                    if (called != null)
                    {
                        deps.Add((ms.ToDisplayString(), called.ToDisplayString()));
                    }
                }
            }
            else if (symbol is INamedTypeSymbol ts)
            {
                symbols.Add(new {
                    Kind = "Type",
                    Name = ts.ToDisplayString(),
                    Accessibility = ts.DeclaredAccessibility.ToString(),
                    TypeKind = ts.TypeKind.ToString()
                });
            }
        }
        files.Add(new {
            Project = proj.Name,
            FilePath = doc.FilePath,
            Symbols = symbols
        });
    }
}

By understanding and implementing Roslyn SDK and then running it over the entire codebase, i now had a semantic model and a syntax tree as a starting point. Using Roslyn, I extracted metadata like the list of classes, their methods, and even metrics such as lines of code per method. One major benefit was Roslyn’s semantic model- we can resolve variable types, inheritance hierarchies, and references across the project. For example, if a VB module used an ambiguous API, Roslyn helped pinpoint exactly which library it referred to. These insights are not just academic; it directly informs and assists the conversion strategy. I valued how Roslyn provided transparency into the legacy code. It was like shining a flashlight into a black box- suddenly a new developer had a clear map of what they were dealing with. Knowing the code’s structure allowed me to plan the AI summarization better (for instance, we could break the code into logical units for the LLM). 

 

Summarize: Explaining Code with an LLM

Understanding code isn’t just a compilation exercise – it’s also about human comprehension. This is where Large Language Model (LLM) step came in. I used the llama model to generate natural-language summaries for the VB.NET code. The goal was to produce clear explanations of what each part of the code did, which would serve as documentation and help verify the converted C# logic later. To do this, I tool fed code snippets into the LLM with prompts like “Explain what this function does.” The result was a concise paragraph describing the code’s purpose and behavior in plain English. This process known as code summarization – automatically produces a natural language description of a code snippet. Such code summaries are immensely valuable for software maintenance, effectively creating documentation for complex functions and making large codebases easier to navigate.

 

var codeMapPath = Path.Combine(analysisDir, "code_map.json");
var codeMap = JsonNode.Parse(await File.ReadAllTextAsync(codeMapPath))!.AsArray();
var sumDir = Path.Combine(jobDir, "summaries");
Directory.CreateDirectory(sumDir);

foreach (var fileEntry in codeMap)
{
    var filePath = (string?)fileEntry!["FilePath"] ?? "";
    var symbols = fileEntry!["Symbols"]?.ToJsonString() ?? "[]";
    var prompt = $@"
            Explain this VB.NET file in clear, simple terms for a new joinee in the team.

            Context:
            - File path: {filePath}
            - Symbols: {symbols}

            Format: Markdown.
            ";
    var req = new
    {
        model = LLM_MODEL,
        messages = new object[] {
            new { role="system", content="You are a concise, accurate code explainer." },
            new { role="user", content=prompt }
        },
        temperature = 0.2
    };

    using var http = new HttpClient { BaseAddress = new Uri(LLM_BASE) };
    var resp = await http.PostAsync("/chat/completions", 
                                    new StringContent(JsonSerializer.Serialize(req), 
                                    Encoding.UTF8, "application/json"));
    var json = JsonNode.Parse(await resp.Content.ReadAsStringAsync())!;
    var content = (string?)json?["choices"]?[0]?["message"]?["content"] ?? "";

    var mdOut = Path.Combine(sumDir, $"{Path.GetFileName(filePath)}.md");
    await File.WriteAllTextAsync(mdOut, content);

Note that codeMap variable is nothing but the output of Roslyn's analysis containing semantic models and syntax trees. The output was one markdown file per .vb file- containing a natural language summary of what that file does. The LLM is a helper here, which is creating fresh documentation of code without manual analysis. 

 

Convert: Translating VB.NET to C# with Roslyn-Based Tools

Finally, we get to the core of the project- converting the code from VB.NET to C#. After ingestion, analysis and summarization, we proceeded to translate the code itself. Rather than hand-coding the translation (which would be a massive effort and risk human error), I again utilized an open-source code conversion tool built on Roslyn. This tool essentially acts as a translator between the two languages, parsing VB.NET with Roslyn and outputting equivalent C# code. Thanks to Roslyn’s ability to consider the full project context during conversion. This means it knows about cross-file references, project-wide imports, etc., ensuring a more accurate result. 

 

Conclusion: A Smooth Journey with Open-Source and AI

What once required 10 developers and over 6 months 15 yrs back, can now be executed single-handedly by one skilled developer using AI tools which are air-gapped for privacy.  The POC demonstrated not just technical feasibility, but also how AI can accelerate understanding, documentation, and validation- making legacy modernization far more accessible and efficient.

 

The Evolving Role of the Product Manager

This POC was not just about technical transformation POC- it was about understanding the impact of AI in our daily work. As a product manager, I realized that to smartly leverage AI in products and design new features, one must evolve to understand the inner workings of these technologies. AI is no longer just a backend tool; it’s a strategic asset that can reshape workflows, reduce costs, and unlock new possibilities for innovation. This POC helped me understand how modern AI tools are accelerating work at an unseen pace and accuracy, and also kickstarted my journey into learning from a familiar project- one which i reimagined with AI.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to recieve normal stock for WBS projec...
entry.content:
There are couple of issues with your requirement and setup.

1.  In order to manage inventory on a project you have to select Valuated or Non-Valuated Stock.  You cannot select No Project Stock.  No Project Stock means that POs are immediately expensed to a project and never visible in inventory management.

2. You should select Valuated Stock.

3. You can't mix Project Stock demands and Plant Stock inventory, you have to pick one or the other.  Sounds like your requirement is to use Plant Stock inventory.

4. In a PS project you add material component demands to a Network Activity using "L" Stock Item.  This is your project material planning. 

5. In the Material Master for the components set the Ind/Coll indicator to 2 for Collective Only on the MRP4 tab.  This will insure the demands are all grouped together under Plant Stock.

6. With steps 4 and 5 you can run MRP and it will match the demand to current inventory or create a planned order for make parts or a PR for buy parts.

7.  You do not need to create PIRs

entry.title: SAP Developer News 16th October, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION 

VIDEO: https://youtu.be/mYlxjg16bo4

PODCAST: https://podcast.opensap.info/sap-developers/2025/10/23/sap-developer-news-october-23rd-2025/ 

Innersource Summit 2025 

  • Blog post: https://community.sap.com/t5/berlin-blog-posts/sap-mitsubishi-electric-and-ibm-will-co-host-the-innersource-summit-join-us/ba-p/14240606?source=social-Global-YouTube-No-Developer_Community-SAPTechEd-Audience_Engagement_%2F_Develop_Community-Community_Topic-Video-18471776374&campaigncode=CRM-YA23-SMS-1941768&sprinklrid=18471776374 
  • LinkedIn post: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/dellagustin_innersource-summit-2025-activity-7383549127776690176-nZPG/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAAXV8RABBNOYkSYKm-L3OOMbqxFSWK5zb8g 
  • Event link: https://innersourcecommons.org/events/isc-2025/ 
  • Mastodon/Fediverse:  https://fosstodon.org/@dellagustin/115367633710981210 
  • BlueSky: https://bsky.app/profile/innersource.bsky.social/post/3m2rzrmmspk2j 
  • X/Twitter: https://x.com/sapopensource/status/1976679116695888151 

BTP Trial Update: CF Runtime Availability 

  • Blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/btp-trial-update-cf-runtime-availability/ba-p/14247240 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud deep-dives 

  • SAP Business Data Cloud – An Architecture Deep Dive: https://community.sap.com/t5/devtoberfest/sap-business-data-cloud-an-architecture-deep-dive/ev-p/14214642 
  • Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/provisioning-sap-business-data-cloud-connect-and-enrolling-with-existing/ba-p/14237512  
  • People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud is Generally Available: https://community.sap.com/t5/delivery-blog-posts/people-intelligence-in-sap-business-data-cloud-is-generally-available/ba-p/14240825  
  • Data and Analytics (DA) at SAP TechEd: https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/tracks-inperson/page/data-and-analytics  

 

Developing Mobile Apps with AI Agents: Introducing the MCP Server for MDK 

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/developing-mobile-apps-with-ai-agents-introducing-the-mcp-server-for-mobile/ba-p/14237709 
  • https://github.com/SAP/mdk-mcp-server 

 

SAP TechEd 2025 

  • Event Site: https://www.sap.com/events/teched.html 

 

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 Innersource Summit 2025 

1:09 BTP Trial Update: CF Runtime Availability 

2:00 SAP Business Data Cloud deep-dives 

3:10 Developing Mobile Apps with AI Agents: Introducing the MCP Server for MDK 

4:08 SAP TechEd 

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for October 23rd, 2025.

[Ajay] Everyone. Have you ever heard about Innersource? It is the practice of applying open source methodologies, culture, and best practices to the in-house software development. SAP is co-hosting and co-organizing the Innersource Summit in Berlin this year. If you want to know more about it, it is a great opportunity for you. The InnerSource Summit 2025 will take place on November 13th, 2025 across Berlin, Yokohama, and New York. It is hosted by SAP, Mitsubishi Electric, and IBM. The agenda is filled with topics about open-source-inspired collaborations, InnerSource analytics, state of InnerSource in the industry, measuring cross-team collaboration, scientific research about InnerSource, and much more. Join the event in person on-site or virtually online. Check the blog post by Gillyherme to find the agenda and how to get the tickets. Links will be available in the description below.

[DJ] Here is an important item for users of the SAP BTP trial account landscape. It concerns the Cloud Foundry runtime specifically. Owing to a high amount of misuse of this part of the platform, the offering for the Cloud Foundry runtime will be drastically restricted for the time being. The main difference for us is that for this period we won't be able to deploy to a CF runtime. Remember, this is regarding the trial landscape only. We strongly advise you to check out Karen Burke's blog post and stay tuned to that for updates. You can also, of course, ask questions there as comments on that blog post if you need to. Link to the blog post is in the description.

[Witalij] As the Devtoberfest first concludes, we hope you joined the sessions on SAP Business Data Cloud, including the architectural deep dive led by the product CTO. While Bjorn delivered a comprehensive overview, the 30-minute format limited the depth of the coverage for key topics such as data products, BW and BDC, or SAP Databricks, but each of which was explored in dedicated sessions earlier this month. Refer to the dedicated blog post for additional insights on Business Data Cloud Connect. BDC Connect is a newly launched service designed to facilitate secure, bi-directional, and zero-copy data product sharing between SAP BDC and external partner systems. Early adopters include Databricks and Google Cloud. Nedel Eduardo provides a detailed walkthrough in a separate post for technical specifics on provisioning BDC Connect. We look forward to seeing you at SAP TechEd on tour and virtually in November, where hands-on workshops will offer practical experience with these advancements. Stay tuned for more.

[Kevin] Hey everybody, if you are a mobile developer, kit developer building cross-platform applications for mobile devices, I got good news for you. The team just released the MDK MCP server on GitHub. It's open source and you can easily install it via NPM on your local machine. You can use the MCP server from out of Klein or GitHub Copilot to not only bootstrap new MDK applications but also enhance your existing ones with new features. It has a port for access to the MDK CLI tools. So you have the whole tool set at your fingertips to build great mobile applications. If you want to find out more, there is a blog post in the community explaining all the details and linking to all the additional resources for you. As always, you can find the link to the blog post in the description of our news video.

[Tom] As this episode of the developer news reaches you, we're nearing the end of Devtoberfest. It's been a great four weeks and I hope that you've enjoyed the time and learned a lot. But you know what the end of Devtoberfest means — the start of SAP TechEd. Whether you plan to join us in person in Berlin, on the virtual platform, or at one of the many TechEd on tour stops around the world, we look forward to bringing you TechEd. Our team at the Developer Advocates is busy getting ready for the developer garage, hands-on workshops, community talks, as well as, of course, the developer keynote. We can't wait to show you all the great new things that are planned for this year, and we look forward to seeing you at TechEd.

entry.title: Help Us Shape the CX Intelligent App: Call for Customer Design Partners
entry.content:
TL;DR: We’re inviting CROs, CMOs, COOs, and their teams to co‑create the new CX Intelligent Application—an insight app that unifies data from SAP Sales Cloud, SAP Commerce Cloud, and SAP S/4HANA, powered by SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Technology Platform. Join brief intro calls, periodic update sessions, and hands‑on feedback workshops to influence the roadmap and experience from day one.

Why this matters for revenue, marketing, and operations leaders

Leaders today are expected to steer growth with speed and precision—yet critical signals often live in different systems. The CX Intelligent Application puts your sales and commerce signals in one place and turns them into unified, actionable insights you can use to prioritize, decide, and act - faster.

What is the CX Intelligent App?

The CX Intelligent Application is an advanced insight app designed for CRO, CMO, and COO teams. It seamlessly combines data from SAP Sales Cloud, SAP Commerce Cloud, and SAP S/4HANA, leveraging the power of SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Technology Platform.

What you can expect:

  • One view of revenue & commerce health across channels, customers, and products
  • Decision‑ready insights that highlight trends, risks, and opportunities
  • Clear, executive‑friendly narratives that frame “what changed, why it matters, and what to do next”
  • Actionability rooted in your SAP landscape, designed to fit exec workflows

SAP product focus: SAP Sales Cloud • SAP Commerce Cloud • SAP Engagement Cloud

What we’re doing - and where you come in

Our goal is to validate value and usability with C‑level leaders and their direct staff. We want your candid feedback on how the app supports data‑driven decisions, integrates multi‑solution insights, and enables more efficient sales and commerce processes.

How we’ll collaborate

  1. Kickoff (short intro call): We’ll walk through the concept and architecture and align on success criteria.
  2. Regular update sessions: We’ll share progress, upcoming features, and open questions, and we’ll listen to your pain points and ideas.
  3. Hands‑on feedback workshops: Explore click‑through prototypes and provide input on user experience, KPIs, and the insights that matter most to you.

Your expertise will directly shape what we prioritize next.

Who should participate?

  • Chief Revenue Officers, Chief Marketing Officers, Chief Operating Officers
  • Strategy, Ops, and Analytics leaders supporting the C‑suite
  • Organizations using (or planning to use) SAP Sales Cloud, SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP Engagement Cloud, and/or SAP S/4HANA

What’s in it for you

  • Early influence: Directly shape an executive‑grade insight app before GA
  • Relevance: Ensure the insights reflect your KPIs, motions, and governance
  • Speed to value: Help us remove friction between data, insight, and action
  • Visibility: Option for an executive readout summarizing what we learned together

What the commitment looks like

  • A brief intro call to align on goals
  • Periodic update sessions to review progress and share feedback
  • Targeted workshops to test prototypes and suggest enhancements

(We’ll keep participation lightweight and respectful of executive time.)

How to join

  • Step 1: Indicate your interest: Sign up here 
  • Step 2: We’ll schedule the intro call and share next steps
  • Step 3: You’ll be invited to updates and hands‑on workshops

Prefer email? Reach out to kim.haller@sap.com
You can also comment below and we’ll reach out.

entry.title: Re: Given an ABAP table, is there a way to do Impact **bleep**...
entry.content:
Use SE11 for the table name, use the "where used" function and select option "Views".

Results will include CDS views as well as SE11 maintained DD views. Depending on your version of S/4, the details option on each result will show you information about the CDS view.

entry.title: Extend C_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt with custom fields in Fiori app Manage Purchase Requisitions (F2229)
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We want to extend Account Assignment table in Purchase Requisition Item with a few custom fields (columns) that are added using Append Structure in table EBKN. From our understanding, we need to extend the CDS view C_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt. 

This CDS view seems to have a chain of CDS selection before finally getting the data from table EBKN, i.e. C_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt -> T_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt -> I_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt -> I_PurReqnAcctAssgmt -> I_PurReqnAcctAssgmtBasic -> EBKN.

After checking some documentation, we found another CDS view E_Purreqnacctassgmt, which we thought could be used, but extending it doesn't help us in accessing those custom fields in C_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt or directly in the Fiori app.

Could someone suggest which CDS views we should extend to get these columns (custom fields) in the Fiori app, or is there a better way?

We tried checking first in Custom Fields and Logic app for a relevant Business Context for PR Account Assignment, but couldn't find anything appropriate. We still would like to keep our development as clean-core as possible.

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
@cchennault , the schedule for EhP8 HRSPs is at https://support.sap.com/en/release-upgrade-maintenance/maintenance-information/schedules-for-maintenance-deliveries/hrsp.html (or go to https://support.sap.com, click on Maintenance -> Schedules for Maintenance Deliveries -> SAP ERP Human Capital Management -> EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 / HR Renewal 2.0).

Based on that calendar, HRSP F1 is expected to be released on November 6th.

And, yes, your understanding is correct. As long as you've applied HRSP F0 to get YELC 2025 Phase I in place, then you can achieve Phase II via regular Notes in SNOTE.

Cheers,
Matt
